title: Nikolay Vuich
text:
Nikolay Vasilyevich Vuich (also spelled Nikolaj Vasiljevič Vujič or Nikolaj Vasiljević Vujić; ;1765–27 March 1836) was an <a href="Imperial%20Russia">Imperial Russian</a> general who fought in the <a href="Russo-Swedish%20War%20%281788-1790%29">Russo-Swedish War</a>, <a href="Russo-Turkish%20War%20%281787-1792%29">Russo Turkish War</a>, the Polish campaign and the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>. He distinguished himself in all the wars in defense of Imperial Russia and contributed his mite in the success of the Coalition forces against Napoleon. His portrait now hangs at the 1812 <a href="Military%20Gallery%20of%20the%20Winter%20Palace">Military Gallery of the Winter Palace</a>.
Biography.
His ancestors moved to Russia from Serbian lands in the middle of the 18th century. Russian military service records show that he enlisted in the 12th Akhtyrsky <a href="Hussar">Hussar</a> Regiment on 12 December 1777. He moved to the Belarusian <a href="J%C3%A4ger%20%28infantry%29">Yaeger</a> Corps on 8 April 1787 with the rank of <a href="ensign">ensign</a>.
In 1790, he was made <a href="captain">captain</a> for the assault on the fortress of <a href="Izmail">Izmail</a>. For bravery exhibited in the <a href="Polish-Russian%20War%20of%201792">Polish-Russian War of 1792</a>, he received the rank of <a href="major">major</a>. He was commander of the 11th (previously 12th) <a href="Chasseur">Chasseur</a>s Regiment (from 10 September 1800, with a break from 27 March to 28 August 1803). He was promoted to the rank of <a href="colonel">colonel</a> on 18 September 1803.
In the 1806–1807 campaign in Poland, with the rank of colonel, he was decorated for bravery <a href="Battle%20of%20Eylau">at Eylau</a> and against the Swedes. Later, in 1812 Vuich fought at <a href="Battle%20of%20Vitebsk%20%281812%29">Vitebsk</a>and <a href="Battle%20of%20Smolensk%20%281812%29">Smolensk</a> with distinction.
Battle of Borodino.
Under commander-in-chief <a href="Barclay%20de%20Tolly">Barclay de Tolly</a> in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Borodino">Battle of Borodino</a>, Vuich was ordered to mount a bayonet charge to gain control of a bridge over the Kolocha River. Colonel Vuich, whose Jaeger Brigade was closest to the bridge, had only eight battalions but they were intact, and the French were repulsed with heavy casualties. His <a href="sapper">sapper</a>s then blew up the bridge. At the same time, another Russian general <a href="Nikolay%20Raevsky">Nikolay Raevsky</a> needed help and three Jaeger regiments under Vuich's command went to assist Raevsky to protect the right-wing of the Russian Army, better known as the "Raevsky Redoubt".That year (21 November 1812) Vuich was elevated to <a href="major%20general">major general</a>.
In the second period of the war, Vuich participated in the attack on the city of Vereya, in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Maloyaroslavets">Battle of Maloyaroslavets</a> and the <a href="Battle%20of%20Krasnoi">Battle of Krasnoi</a>. 
For exceptional bravery demonstrated at Maloyaroslavets, he received from the Tsar the <a href="Golden%20Weapon%20%26quot%3BFor%20Bravery%26quot%3B">Golden Weapon</a> with diamonds. He participated in 1813 and 1814 campaigns against <a href="Napoleonic%20France">Napoleonic France</a> garnering the <a href="Order%20of%20St.%20George">Order of St. George</a>, 3rd Class (awarded on 30 March 1813), and taking command of the 24th Infantry Division. Appointed commander of the 3rd Brigade of the 24th Infantry Division, Vuich was part of the Northern Army in the campaign of 1813–1814 that participated in the battles of <a href="Battle%20of%20Dennewitz">Dennewitz</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Leipzig">Leipzig</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Craonne">Craonne</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Laon">Laon</a> and the taking of <a href="Battle%20of%20Paris%20%281814%29">Paris</a>, for which he was awarded <a href="Order%20of%20Saint%20Anna">Order of Saint Anna</a>, 1st degree, and Order of St. George, 3rd class, as well as diamond signs to the Order of Saint Anna, 1st degree.
On 27 November 1816, he became the head of the 24th Infantry Division and on 11 November 1827, the 18th Infantry Division.He was <a href="ennobled">ennobled</a> on 28 November 1829.
Nikolay Vasilyevich Vuich died in 1836.
His grandson Nicholas Vuich was a Russian senator during the reign of Czar <a href="Nicholas%20II%20of%20Russia">Nicholas II of Russia</a>.
